try this: open up a terminal, and type "ls -ld .gnupg"
to be more specific, "ls -ld ${HOME}/.gnupg"
drwxrwxr-x 2 root balaji 4096 2008-12-05 18:41 .gnupg

yeah that's...incorrect. two things: you don't want user root owning the directory, and the permissions are not nearly restrictive enough. try this: "sudo chown -R balaji .gnupg", and then "chmod 700 .gnupg"
now drwx------ 2 balaji balaji 4096 2008-12-05 18:41 /home/balaji/.gnupg
